habitat: Grows on stumps or trunks of hardwoods like oak, maple, and hemlock; thrives in moist, shady spots across Asia, North America, and Europe; fruits late summer to early autumn.
shortDescription: A medicinal mushroom with a large, dark, glossy, woody fruiting body, revered in traditional Chinese medicine. Known for bioactive compounds with potential health benefits.
edibility: Not typically consumed fresh due to bitter, woody texture; used in teas, powders, extracts, and supplements for medicinal purposes.
benefitsOrToxicity: Contains triterpenoids, polysaccharides, and peptidoglycans with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, immunomodulatory, stress-reducing, potential anti-cancer, liver-supporting, sleep-promoting, and cardiovascular benefits. May interact with blood thinners, chemotherapy, immunosuppressants, and liver-processed drugs. Limited safety data in pregnancy and breastfeeding. Rare reports of liver toxicity and chronic diarrhea.

identification.cap: 3–20 cm; rounded, fan-shaped, or kidney-shaped; red-brown or dark brown with a varnished, glossy surface and radial grooves; edges sharp, sometimes wavy with whitish, yellow, or reddish tones.
identification.poreSurface: Tubular hymenophore; whitish/cream turning brown; pores 0.15–0.25 mm, 4–5 per mm; darkens when dry or touched.
identification.stem: 3–15 cm long, 1–3 cm thick; often lateral, occasionally central; chestnut or dark brown with a purple-brown shine; uneven surface.
identification.flesh: Spongy when young, becomes dense and hard with age; whitish to brown or wood-colored.

medicinalProperties: Reishi supports liver function, immune health, stress reduction, improved sleep, antioxidant protection, anti-inflammatory effects, cardiovascular support, potential anti-cancer effects, and skin health. Used in teas, tinctures, powders, capsules, infused wine, coffee, and skincare products.
note: Cultivation requires warm temperatures, high humidity, indirect light, and hardwood substrates (logs or sawdust). Dried mushrooms are used for medicinal preparations.
